rComments: Dr. Nielsen is a great professor. He's always prepared, and he's great at engaging his students. His tests are quite hard but fair. Overall great guy with a huge passion for physics

Nielsen is nerdy, but passionate and not arrogant at all. He is very approachable and does examples in class, many of which are from the textbook. He trips up on math sometimes, but quickly corrects himself.

Mr. Nielsen is a good lecturer and has worked at the LHC and is well respected among his peers. The tests are difficult, and the curve is generous. But be prepared to spend some hours on the homework and make sure to take full advantage of MSI and TA hours. It really helps!
awesome professor

Prof Nielsen loves physics, and seems to hope you will too. Tests and homework are certainly difficult, but I like to think that the people who will go on to build bridges and such were thoroughly vetted. Expect to give it your utmost.

His tests are impossible to score 100% unless you have taken physics beforehand. The average of the class throughout the quarter was a 50%. It's very important to do all of the examples in the text and to understand how to do the problems. This class was harder than my engineering classes. Don't take this class unless it's required.

Homework is much harder than the tests, but he is very friendly and helpful. Tests are not impossible, but very challenging in my opinion. His tests mostly test concepts and logic, not just formulas (such a problem that takes longer finding ways to solve rather than actually solving it). Great and funny instructor overall.

He makes a lot of physics jokes that people don't laugh at, but I think he is hilarious. This is a really interesting class, he is very clear, and his lecturing style is helpful because he writes everything down on a big projector. If you have any physics question go ask him after class, he loves answering them and is a super helpful guy!

Jason is an okay teacher, and he tries to help you in office hour. His tests are neither hard nor easy. Although he curves a lot. a 70 and above on our midterms was an A. He made the final a little easier too. He uses clicker questions but it's not really a big deal. Just do your homework and go to sections, office hours.

After taking AP Physics in high school, Nielson's 5A class iss a walk in the park. The tests are very fair, and simple to prepare for. The labs are mundane, but at this level they have to be. Homework is ultimately doable, and if you do well on the tests it's not necessary to get a high homework score to get an A in the class.
Jason is a boss. He worked on the Large Hadron Collider so you know he's legit. His class is easy. If you do the homework and study a few hours before the exams you will get an A.

I took AP physics in high school, and that was all I needed to have done to get an A+ in this class. The average student in 5A isn't the sharpest tool in the shed, so getting over 100% after the curve on all three of the exams is very doable.
The homework is MUCH harder than the tests. It usually helps to come to class having already briefed yourself on the topic beforehand; the book isnt always helpful though.

exams are impossible; my 44% on midterm #2 however was curved to a 80%, so the curve is fair. Weekly homework is extremely difficult, you must attend section to get all the problems correct and it is 15% of grade... 6/9 scores on HW added up :/ He pretty much covered my entire high school physics course in 4 weeks so it's difficult to keep up.

Nielson is a really nice guy and speaks very clearly.  Daily clicker questions make it manditory to go to class.  Really hard tests and homework sets, but the curve is fair.  Recommended only for students that have 5A as a requirement.

Jason is cool and very approachable. He is really friendly during office hours, and are more than willing to explain the concepts of Physics that weren't clear in lecture. This is a hard class, so it is recommended only for the ones who really like and really wanna learn Physics. Homework is NOT online, thank god.

Homework was much harder than the tests. You need to study and you need to pay attention, this isn't an easy class. Nielsen is great, but he gets side tracked here and there. He'll always answer your questions. If you put effort into this class and can do algebra, you can pass.

Somewhat confusing at times, but readily explains things further upon being asked.  It's hard, certainly, but... it's physics.  Not much you can do about that.  Tests were curved pretty fairly.  Very friendly, nice, and easy to get along with.  Cares a lot about his students.

Tests are murder. The average on the exams for the class is about 50 points out of 100. He does curve the exams. His lectures can get derailed very quickly if somebody asks a question. It's difficult to follow along sometimes, his notation gets awkward, then he realizes it's awkward, and changes it, which makes it worse, lol. This is a tough class.

He tries hard at explaining but can be very unclear without knowing it. Prone to going off on tangents that don't help forward the class much. Tests are much harder than book HW. Poor test wording makes the problems very difficult when they normally wouldn't be. Previous experience in physics expected. Important derivations in lecture, don't skip.
Really liked him. Started out boring, got fun as quarter went on. Good at connecting ideas with real applications. Exams are hell.
